conclusion: The lamp providing illumination is pulled straight back, farther from the objects but not moved sideways or up/down.
The direction of the light does not change, only its distance.
The bundle of rays that reaches the scene becomes straighter (more nearly parallel).
Shadows on the floor contract toward the points directly under the objects, and their tips slide back toward the objects while keeping the same overall orientation.
A is the long rectangular part of the bird-cage shadow.
A slides toward the cage and shortens markedly; the rectangle becomes progressively smaller.
B is the tip of the same shadow (bird-cage shadow).

B moves more rapidly toward the cage because it is farthest from the object now, and its size shrinks; eventually it may merge with the rest of the cageâ€™s shadow so the two-part look (A + B) disappears.
C is the conical lampshade shadow.
C moves almost straight inward toward the foot of the lamp, its triangular outline keeps the same angles but its overall length and width diminish.
D is the farthest part of the jewelled-cross shadow.
D slides back toward the body of the cross, every arm of the cross appears shorter, so the entire silhouette becomes a compact, smaller cross lying closer to the object.

All four labelled regions shift toward their respective objects and become smaller; no region moves sideways to a new azimuth and the original orientations are preserved, but the foreshortening grows as the light recedes.
